items.title: Demo app crashes with wx toolkit backend

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
Interestingly, the demo scripts can be run standalone but they crash in the demo application e.g. the "Standard Editors/Boolean Editor demo".

<details><summary>Packages in EDM environment (listed using pip instead of edm)</summary>

```
(ets-demo-app-wx) >pip freeze
appdirs==1.4.3
apptools==4.5.0
comtypes==1.1.7
configobj==5.0.6
distribute-remove==1.0.0
docutils==0.16
eam==1.4.2
etsdemo==0.1.0
h5py==2.10.0
MKL==2018.0.3
numexpr==2.6.9
numpy==1.19.1
packaging==16.8
pandas==0.25.3
Pillow==7.2.0
pyface==7.1.0.dev104
Pygments==2.2.0
pyparsing==2.2.0
pytables==3.5.1
python-dateutil==2.8.0
pytz==2018.9
six==1.11.0
traits==6.1.1
traitsui==7.1.0.dev266
wxPython==4.1.0
```

</details>

NOTE : I had to install pyface and traitsui from git source e.g. `edm run -e ets-demo-app-wx -- python -m pip install --upgrade git+http://github.com/enthought/pyface.git#egg=pyface`.

items.title: Better information about missing dependencies in demo application

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
At the moment, there are a number of demo scripts that can be "clicked on" from the ETS Demo application which won't display anything in the "Demo" area. This is because the demo scripts need dependencies which aren't available in a basic ets demo application. At the moment, missing dependencies aren't reported in the application.

For example

- "Adapted tree editor demo" requires apptools,
- "HDF5 tree demo" requires pytables,
- "HDF5 tree demo2" requires h5py etc.

Some of the demo scripts explicitly mention the need for additional packages in the description e.g. "To run this demonstration successfully, you must have the AppTools egg installed." in "Adapted tree editor demo" but the other two in the aforementioned list don't explicitly state this requirement.

1. It would be nice if all of the demo scripts that depend on additional packages explicitly document that dependence in the description.
2. It would be nicer if we can update `demo` section of traitsui ``__extras_requires__`` to list **all** demo dependencies. That way, users can simply do `pip install traitsui[demo]` and won't have to worry about any missing dependencies.

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/3e3a05a52215e33d88fab882e0f7f27638aa8eb4/traitsui/__init__.py#L30

items.title: Missing/broken "?" icon on etsdemo app

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
Steps to reproduce
---------------------

- `edm envs create ets-demo-app` (creates a python 3.6 environment)
- `edm install -e ets-demo-app etsdemo pyqt5 eam` (`eam` is optional)
- `edm run -e ets-demo-app -- pip install --upgrade git+http://github.com/enthought/traitsui.git#egg=traitsui`
- Launch the application

![broken-icon-etsdemo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926457/89759487-d2f12980-dad9-11ea-8244-8eeb43bab33e.png)

Observed on Win 10.

items.title: Wx ListStrEditor with right_clicked hooks raises IndexError

labels.name: difficulty: easy
labels.description: Issues which don't need much/any context about the package.

items.body:
On Wx, right clicking anywhere in an ListStrEditor that isn't referring to an item raises IndexError if the list is empty.

To reproduce:
```
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *

class ListStrModel(HasTraits):
    value = List([])

view = View(
    Item(
        "value",
        editor=ListStrEditor(
            right_clicked="object.right_clicked",
            right_clicked_index="object.right_clicked_index",
        ),
    )
)

ListStrModel().configure_traits(view=view)
```

Right clicking anywhere in the widget produces this:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/wx/list_str_editor.py", line 561, in _right_clicked
    self.object, self.name, index
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/list_str_adapter.py", line 212, in get_item
    return self._result_for("get_item", object, trait, index)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/list_str_adapter.py", line 322, in _result_for
    self.item = item = items[index]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

The fix is simple: it should be a matter of checking if the `index` is `-1` in `_right_clicked` and skip the rest.

items.title: Deprecation warnings with Python 3.8 on collections ABC

labels.name: difficulty: easy
labels.description: Issues which don't need much/any context about the package.

items.body:
Running the test suite with Python 3.8 reveals the following warning:
```
test_undo (traitsui.tests.test_undo.TestEditorUndo) ... /Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/undo.py:154: DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is deprecated since Python 3.3, and in 3.9 it will stop working
  elif isinstance(v1, collections.Sequence):
```

items.title: In etsdemo application descriptions don't render html tags

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body: In many examples the docstrings will have things like TreeEditor or apptools.io.file.File, etc. but these don't show up as bold or italicized, instead the tags are simply written into the description. In other files, such as https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/traitsui/examples/demo/Dynamic_Forms/visible_when.py , The formatting in correctly rendered, e.g. " \*\*Detail:\*\* " appears as **Detail:** in the application

items.title: Some occurrences of on_trait_change in demo code
items.body: Should transition to using observe

items.title: Resizeable windows opened with edit_traits() are forced to the background
items.body:
Hello everyone,

Since the latest update (TraitsUI 7.0.1-1), I have noticed what I think is unwanted behaviour.

Whenever I open a second window with the `edit_traits()` function, and the resizable property of this View is set to True, the window is hidden behind the first window (which was called through `configure_traits()`).

Below is a demo case. Try opening a second window through the menu bar of the 'Main' window, this should trigger the bug. I am using PyQt5:

```
from traitsui.api import Handler, View, Item
from traits.api import HasTraits, String, Int
from traitsui.menu import Menu, Action, CloseAction, MenuBar

the_action = Action(
    name = "Open a window",
    action = "_do_something"
)

class Sub(HasTraits):
    a_trait = Int
    
    def default_traits_view(self):
        return View(
            Item("a_trait"),
            resizable = True
        )
    
class DemoHandler(Handler):
    def _do_something(self, uiinfo):
        sub_window = Sub()
        sub_window.edit_traits()

class Main(HasTraits):
    name = String

    traits_view = View(
        Item("name"),
        menubar = MenuBar(
            Menu(
                the_action,
                name = "A menu"
            )
        ),
        handler = DemoHandler()
    )

main = Main()
main.configure_traits()
```

Kind regards,

Matthias

items.title: [on master] Broken links in demos page in docs

labels.name: type: urgent
labels.description: Issues that are a priority and need to be fixed as soon as possible.

items.body:
The "demos" page in the traitsui docs points to the code on github for the various examples on github. BUT. the code got moved recently to now live inside the traitsui package instead of at the top-level of the github repository.

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/f3a757638e085b7b175cb1d2bcafdc2898f6dbba/docs/source/conf.py#L192-L196

An alternative - to ensure that the links are never broken but possibly outdated - is to permalink to a specific commit when the page was last updated/verified.

items.title: Warnings in Demo code docstrings

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
Many of the etc-demo code examples (found here  https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/tree/master/traitsui/examples/demo) contain a warning in their doctoring that the example may not work correctly.  
e.g
"
**WARNING**

  This demo might not work as expected and some documented features might be
  missing.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"


In many cases though, these examples seem to have been fixed and are working properly.  These warnings should be removed.

items.title: Continuous integration test for support of Traits 6.0
items.body:
Currently CI tests against Traits 6.1.0 and does not test against Traits 6.0.0, and it would be easy to accidentally use new features of Traits 6.1.0 without realizing that would be in effect dropping support against Traits 6.0.

Actions:
- Decide if the next release can drop support for Traits 6.0
- If not, add a CI job to test against Traits 6.0

items.title: PNG icons aren't supported as desktop shortcut icons by edm/eam

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
The etsdemo explicitly sets an icon - which is used in the EDM GUI application and by the edm/eam machinery to create the shortcut. See https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/5e9043f51818256879f08cf98c3785f67a09f2c0/ets-demo/etsdemo/info.py#L28-L33

From the looks of it, windows shortcuts might not accept a PNG file, which is what we are defining as the icon at the moment. This causes the desktop shortcut icon to look blank/white. See below.

The fix here is to contribute an icon file in a file format that is acceptable on windows (along with mac os and linux) e.g. an ico file. I tested locally with a bmp file (24 bit bitmap to be specific) which worked on windows 10.

NOTE : Double-clicking the icon still does what we expect it to - it launches the application.

![broken-desktop-shortcut](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926457/88046714-ff033580-cb3f-11ea-845f-239622317d00.PNG)

items.title: Missing entry from application schema dict for etsdemo application

labels.name: difficulty: easy
labels.description: Issues which don't need much/any context about the package.

items.body:
The eam documentation mentions the need for a `"default"` key in the schema dictionary when the schema version is 2, which is what we are using. At the moment, not having this key is preventing eam from working as expected - https://docs.enthought.com/eam/metadata_schema.html#version-2

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/4594aaa9430c64e96dbb1313b123739c22631473/ets-demo/etsdemo/info.py#L20-L35

items.title: Discrepancies between Tutorial text and code in Repo
items.body:
There are occasions where the code blocks in the tutorial https://docs.enthought.com/traitsui/tutorials/index.html do not directly line up with their corresponding .py files located in 
code snipperts - https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/tree/master/docs/source/tutorials/code_snippets
(it is possible some of these may have been intentional)

Specifically code snippet 2 
```
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *

class Camera(HasTraits):
    gain = Enum(1, 2, 3, )
    exposure = CInt(10, label="Exposure", )

class TextDisplay(HasTraits):
    string = String()

    view= View( Item('string', show_label=False, springy=True, style='custom' ))

class Container(HasTraits):
    camera = Instance(Camera)
    display = Instance(TextDisplay)

    view = View(
                Item('camera', style='custom', show_label=False, ),
                Item('display', style='custom', show_label=False, ),
            )

container = Container(camera=Camera(), display=TextDisplay())
container.configure_traits()
```
and container.py:
```
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *

class Camera(HasTraits):
    """ Camera object """

    gain = Enum(1, 2, 3,
        desc="the gain index of the camera",
        label="gain", )

    exposure = CInt(10,
        desc="the exposure time, in ms",
        label="Exposure", )

class Display(HasTraits):
    string = String()

    view= View( Item('string', show_label=False, springy=True, style='custom' ))

class Container(HasTraits):
    camera = Instance(Camera, ())
    display = Instance(Display, ())

    view = View(
                Item('camera', style='custom', show_label=False, ),
                Item('display', style='custom', show_label=False, ),
               )

Container().configure_traits()
```


In code snippet 5 the imports are 
```
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import View, Item, ButtonEditor
```
and the last line is `Counter().configure_traits()`.  Whereas in interactive.py it is:
```
from traits import *
from pyface.api import GUI
from traitsui import View, Item, ButtonEditor
```
and 
```
Counter().edit_traits()
GUI().start_event_loop()
```
This interactive.py yields an error mentioned in issue #1036.  I assume it should be replaced by the code snippet code.  

Lastly, the imports of code snippet 7:
```
from threading import Thread
from time import sleep
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import View, Item, ButtonEditor
```
do not match traits_thread.py
```
from threading import Thread
from time import sleep
from traits.api import Button, HasTraits, Instance, Str
from traitsui.api import View, Item
```



As an aside, the names of the .py files are never explicitly mentioned in the tutorial, instead code blocks are simply labeled as "code snippet X".  It isn't difficult to identify the correct files, but a reference to the names, or changing the file names so that there is cleaner alignment might be nice.

Also, where is the code for the Putting it all together section located?  I did not see it in the repo and the link given in the tutorial results in a file not found error.

items.title: Errors and Warnings in the Tutorial code snippets
items.body:
This issue is a fraction of issue #1027.  Specifically it addresses the errors and warnings that occur when running example code located in 
code snipperts - [https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/tree/master/docs/source/tutorials/code_snippets](url)

```
$ python event_loop_qt.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "event_loop_qt.py", line 1, in <module>
    from pyface.qt.QtCore import QApplication
ImportError: cannot import name 'QApplication'
```

```
$ python event_loop_wx.py
event_loop_wx.py:11: wxPyDeprecationWarning: Using deprecated class PySimpleApp. Use :class:`App` instead.
  wx.PySimpleApp().MainLoop()
```

Additionally, the files event_loop.py seems to explicitly use wx, but from the docs it was my understanding that it was toolkit agnostic.  This may not be a problem, but I was confused.  

```
$ python interactive.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "interactive.py", line 3, in <module>
    from traitsui import View, Item, ButtonEditor
ImportError: cannot import name 'View'
```
replacing `from traits import *` and `from traitsui import View, Item, ButtonEditor` with `from traits.api import * ` and `from traitsui.api import * ` solved this issue.  Should imports from traits/traitsui always be replace with traits.api/traitsui.api? 

```
 python mpl_figure_editor.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mpl_figure_editor.py", line 12, in <module>
    from traitsui.wx.editor import Editor
  File "/Users/aayres/.edm/envs/general-use/lib/python3.6/site-packages/traitsui/wx/__init__.py", line 26, in <module>
    from . import toolkit
  File "/Users/aayres/.edm/envs/general-use/lib/python3.6/site-packages/traitsui/wx/toolkit.py", line 43, in <module>
    from .constants import WindowColor, screen_dx, screen_dy
  File "/Users/aayres/.edm/envs/general-use/lib/python3.6/site-packages/traitsui/wx/constants.py", line 79, in <module>
    scrollbar_dx = wx.SystemSettings.GetMetric(wx.SYS_VSCROLL_X)
wx._core.PyNoAppError: The wx.App object must be created first!
```

items.title: Release etsdemo 0.1.0

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
This issue is for releasing the `etsdemo` distribution sitting in this repository's `ets-demo` folder.

This is the first release of etsdemo. Future release process may differ.

Pre-release
------------
- [x] Check metadata in `setup.py` is good, e.g. `url`, `download_url`, `package_data` are correct (#1111)
- [x] Check MANIFEST.in is up-to-date: Build a source distribution and see if it captures the files we want to distribute (#1117)
- [x] Prepare Changelog, open a PR against master (#1109)

Release
--------
- [x] Create a release branch `etsdemo/release/0.1.x`, push to GitHub
- [x] From the master branch, bump the release version to 0.2.0 for the development of the next release, create a PR to target master (#1119)
- [x] Create a new branch from the release branch, set IS_RELEASED flag to True, commit. Open a PR targeting `etsdemo/release/0.1.x` (#1120)
- [x] On the commit where IS_RELEASED is true, tag `git tag -a etsdemo/0.1.0 -m "REL: Release of etsdemo 0.1.0"`. Double check the tag with `git show etsdemo/0.1.0`. Push the tag to GitHub `git push origin etsdemo/0.1.0`.
- [x] Checkout the release commit. Do a `git clean -ffxd` in case. Build a source distribution. Install from source distribution and run tests in a work directory that is out of source.
- [x] Upload to PyPI
- [x] Test the PyPI package

Post-release
-------------
- [x] Request an egg be built for EDM `enthought/free` repo.
- [x] Announcement

Note for future reference: The distribution is currently quite basic. The README already contains all the documentation necessary. Should it need to grow in the future, we may need separate documentation and additional steps for publishing the documentation.

items.title: Configure logging for the demo application main function

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
When the ETS demo application is launched in the production setting, we should configure logging. Currently the main function does not do that:
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/6fccc3966e89a8082aace9623b84a80a74c46f3e/ets-demo/etsdemo/main.py#L22-L27

As a first step, it should log to console.
(In the future it could be extended to logging to files or allow the log level to be modified)

As usual, the log configuration should be implemented as a context manager so that the log configuration is reset when the function exit.

items.title: Add instructions for development

labels.name: difficulty: easy
labels.description: Issues which don't need much/any context about the package.

items.body:
At the moment, there is no obvious way for a developer who isn't familiar with the codebase to understand/infer that the `etstool.py` file is what they need to look at to understand how to setup the development environment and run the test suite.

It would be very useful to have a small section in the README file or a longer DEVELOP.rst file which provide information for developers on setting up the development environment, running flake8 and the test suite etc.

items.title: Remove the top-level tox files

labels.name: difficulty: easy
labels.description: Issues which don't need much/any context about the package.

items.body:
The tox.ini file and the associated requirements file aren't used anywhere and they aren't up-to-date. Given that we already have a working CI system in place, we probably want to remove the two files. We don't have the resources to maintain two different ways to setup and run the testsuite.

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/tox.ini
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/tox-requirements.txt

items.title: Remove top-level setup.cfg file
items.body: The setup.cfg file https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/setup.cfg seems to defining something used by nose but we don't use nose anymore as the test runner (we use unittest) so we can remove this file.

items.title: Remove top-level checksums file
items.body:
A checksums file exists at the top-level : https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/checksums
This seems to have been introduced in the PR https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/pull/221/commits/0c711f1012980cf0fddf1128f768944cd53e2f2b to validate the checksum value of the downloaded wxPython source.

The ci machinery has been updated since then and now, we directly use wheels from https://extras.wxpython.org/wxPython4/extras/linux/gtk3/ubuntu-14.04/. Given this, i think we can simply remove the checksums file.

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/95df8bf239b5ff2abe8cd7e55c73531ed2222b1b/etstool.py#L206-L210

Even if we want to validate the wxPython wheels we are downloading, we will need to take a different approach than the existing checksums file so if i understand correctly, there is no meaningful way to update the existing file for the new usage.

items.title: Remove top-level TODO.txt
items.body:
There is a top-level TODO.txt file which is sitting in the github repository, for reasons i am not aware of. It looks like it was possibly used as a basic issue tracker/todo list for the package. Now that we use GitHub to track issues, we can remove the file, after opening issues for each todo item in the file. 

Ref : https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/TODO.txt

items.title: Qt5 crash when column resize if columns have changed
items.body:
I am seeing hard qt5 crashes (see below for traceback) when removing columns from being displayed in a tabular editor. I have tracked the issue to be due to the qt tabular_editor implementation of `columnResized` which, if the column list has changed might lead to index errors when executing [this](https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/traitsui/qt4/tabular_editor.py#L928) or [this](https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/master/traitsui/helper.py#L168).

Issue seen on OSX and Windows on python 3.6, traitsui 6.1.3 & 7.0.0-2, qt 5.12.6-5, pyqt5 5.14.2-3 all installed from EDM. Not reproducible with Qt4. 

Crash can be reproduced by running [this script](https://github.com/KBIbiopharma/pybleau/blob/master/pybleau/app/ui/dataframe_analyzer_model_view.py) and hiding some columns via the column control (bottom left of top table). Still working on a minimal code to reproduce.

items.title: 'invalid' in Item no longer used for dynamically setting error state

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
In the following example:
```
from traits.api import Bool, HasTraits, Property, Str
from traitsui.api import Item, View
from traitsui.api import TextEditor

class Person(HasTraits):
    name = Str()

    invalid = Property(Bool, depends_on='name')

    def _get_invalid(self):
        # Name is valid iff it doesn't consist entirely of whitespace.
        stripped_name = self.name.strip()
        return stripped_name == ''

    traits_view = View(
        Item('name', invalid='invalid'),
    )

if __name__ == '__main__':
    Person().configure_traits()
```

The text box is expected to be red if all the characters in the field are whitespaces.
This works in 7.0.0 but no longer works on master.

(The example above is adapted from `traitsui/integrationtests/ui/text_editor_invalid.py`. If instead of setting `invalid` on `Item`, set it on the editor factory, then the invalid state works.)

Believed to be a regression from #859, we should fix this before the 7.0.1 release.

items.title: CodeEditor not working with yaml lexer
items.body:
Using a `CodeEditor` with `lexer="yaml"` results in the following error, which also causes the application to crash:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/rpreste/.edm/envs/envivo/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyface/ui/qt4/code_editor/pygments_highlighter.py", line 168, in highlightBlock
    format = self._get_format(token)
  File "/Users/rpreste/.edm/envs/envivo/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyface/ui/qt4/code_editor/pygments_highlighter.py", line 195, in _get_format

    t = cls._styles[token]
KeyError: Token.Literal.Scalar.Plain
```

This also happens with `lexer="salt"`, which highlights yaml + Jinja syntax.

Some sample code to reproduce the issue is included here:

<details>
<summary>Sample</summary>

```python
from traits.api import Code, HasTraits
from traitsui.api import CodeEditor, Item, View


class MyCode(HasTraits):

    code = Code("version: 1")

    def default_traits_view(self):
        return View(
            Item("code", style="readonly",
                 editor=CodeEditor(lexer="yaml")),
        )


if __name__ == "__main__":
    sample = MyCode()
    sample.configure_traits()
```

</details>

items.title: Clarify which version of Qt is skipped/required in tests
items.body: Currently the `is_current_backend_qt4` test utility in `traitsui.tests._tools` refer to both Qt4 and Qt5. This is very confusing, we should differentiate the two versions and possibly create another convenient wrapper for where we only care about whether Qt is used regardless of its version.

items.title: Include example files as package data for TraitsUI

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
Related to #966 

This issue is for making TraitsUI's examples (files in the current `examples` folder) of the package data so that it can be loaded by the demo application upon installation.

Care should be taken to ensure that we **don't** end up including a Python `examples` package that can be imported. The files are data. They are not packages.

items.title: Support contributing demo example data via entry point

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
After #908, the demo application will need to be able to load example files contributed by other projects.

This will involve creating an API for other projects to adhere to.
As a first cut, an entry point should return a path-like object for loading a directory of files and a display name for the data.

For future consideration, not part of this issue:
The API should be extensible so that options can be added.  Some ideas: we might want to extend the API so that projects can omit certain files under certain conditions at runtime, e.g. traitsui can choose to hide examples that require Wx in a Qt environment. There might be conditions that are settable by the users, e.g. traitsui can advertise a set of more mature examples and a set of less stable examples separately (see #949 as well), and the user might be allowed to select them?

items.title: Enable brings in Traits 6.0 instead of 6.1 into CI environment

labels.name: component: test suite
labels.description: Issues related to testing, test support, test interactions...

items.body:
Enable is a dependency of Chaco, which was added as a test dependency to allow automatic testing of examples. It is used by one example `examples/demo/Useful/demo_group_size.py`.

The easiest "fix" would be to exclude this example from automatic testing.

A proper fix would need to modify installation code in `etstool.py`, and I'm not sure what would be the best way to do that in order to have a consistent set of packages.

items.title: TraitsUI Bugfix Release 7.0.1

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
Target date: To be confirmed, will edit here once confirmed.

This is a bug fix release and therefore the procedure will be slightly different compared to a major/minor release.
See https://github.com/enthought/pyface/issues/557 for Pyface release 7.0.1

Pre-release
---
- [x] Verify PRs that need to be merged to the maintanence branch are included in the Release 7.0.1 milestone
- [x] Cherry pick these PRs onto the `fix/7.0.1-bugfixes` branch (see #800)
- [x] Review #800 and merge it to `maint/7.0` branch
- [x] Test against other ETS packages and other traitsui-using projects
- [x] Update changelog and open PR targeting `maint/7.0` branch (#976)
- [x] Check MANIFEST and requirements are still up to date.
- [x] Test building the documentation

Release
-------
- [x] Create PR targeting `maint/7.0` branch. In this PR: (#1003)
        - Set release to `7.0.1`, and set `IS_RELEASED` is true; commit
        - Bump the version to `7.0.2` and set `IS_RELEASED` to false; commit
- [x] On the release commit (where `IS_RELEASED` is true), add an annotated tag, and push the tag
- [x] Make PR targeting `gh-pages` branch: Generate documentation and copy the content to the branch. Verify that the resulting docs/index.html looks good. See https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/pull/787 for a similar PR (#1004)
- [x] Install from source distribution and run tests again
- [x] Upload to PyPI
- [x] Test the PyPI package
- [x] Announcement

Post-release
-------------
- [x] Package update for `enthought/free` repository (for EDM)
- [x] Backport release note and change log to master, and possibly `maint/7.0` branch (#1006)

items.title: editable:False + multi_select:True = segfault with TabularEditor and PyQt5
items.body:
The script below causes a Segmentation fault crash when the user drags a row in the table. In Windows, it causes the application window to freeze.

Specs:

OS: ubuntu 18, windows 10)
Python: 3.6
traitsui 7.0.0
PyQt5 5.14.2

```python
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *


class Thing(HasTraits):
    x = Float()

    def _x_default(self):
        import random
        return random.random()


class Demo(HasTraits):
    things = List(Instance(Thing))

    def default_traits_view(self):
        return View(
            UItem(
                name='things',
                editor=TabularEditor(
                    multi_select=True,
                    editable=False,
                    adapter=TabularAdapter(
                        columns=[('A number', 'x')]
                    )
                )
            ),
            resizable=True,
            width=400,
        )


demo = Demo(things=[Thing() for _ in range(10)])
demo.configure_traits()
```

items.title: EnumEditor fails to launch when combining mapping values and format_func

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
The following example used to work with TraitsUI 7.0:
```
from traits.api import HasStrictTraits, List, Str
from traitsui.api import View, Item, EnumEditor

mapping = {"FLAG_YES": "Yes", "FLAG_NO": "No", "": ""}

class EnumModel(HasStrictTraits):
    value = Str()

enum_editor_factory = EnumEditor(
    values=mapping,
    format_func=lambda v: mapping[v],
    mode="list"
)

view = View(
    Item(
        "value",
        editor=enum_editor_factory,
        style="simple",
    )
)

model = EnumModel()
model.configure_traits(view=view)
```

On master it fails with the following error:
```
...
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/enum_editor.py", line 96, in init
    self.values_changed()
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/enum_editor.py", line 66, in values_changed
    self._value(), self.string_value
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/helper.py", line 76, in enum_values_changed
    data = [(strfunc(v), n) for n, v in values.items()]
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/helper.py", line 76, in <listcomp>
    data = [(strfunc(v), n) for n, v in values.items()]
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/editor.py", line 212, in string_value
    return self.format_func(value)
  File "example2.py", line 12, in <lambda>
    format_func=lambda v: mapping[v],
KeyError: 'Yes'
```

<details><summary>The longer traceback</summary>

```

  File "/Users/kchoi/.edm/envs/traitsui-test-3.6-pyqt/lib/python3.6/site-packages/traits/has_traits.py", line 2088, in configure_traits

    context, view, kind, handler, id, scrollable, args

    context, view, kind, handler, id, scrollable, args
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/view_application.py", line 126, in __init__
    args=self.args,
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/view.py", line 462, in ui
    ui.ui(parent, kind)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/ui.py", line 246, in ui
    self.rebuild(self, parent)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/toolkit.py", line 162, in ui_live
    ui_live.ui_live(ui, parent)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_live.py", line 43, in ui_live
    _ui_dialog(ui, parent, BaseDialog.NONMODAL)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_live.py", line 65, in _ui_dialog
    BaseDialog.display_ui(ui, parent, style)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_base.py", line 284, in display_ui
    ui.owner.init(ui, parent, style)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_live.py", line 225, in init
    self.add_contents(panel(ui), bbox)
  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_panel.py", line 259, in panel

  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/qt4/ui_panel.py", line 874, in _add_items

    self.values_changed()

  File "/Users/kchoi/Work/ETS/traitsui/traitsui/helper.py", line 76, in enum_values_changed
    data = [(strfunc(v), n) for n, v in values.items()]

With TraitsUI 7.0, it "works" because `format_func` wasn't actually used (see #782). For example, if the `format_func` was commented out then the resulting behaviour matches the expectation. #782 is now fixed and results in the above error.

items.title: Make demo application installable from EDM app

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
This issue depends on #904 as it requires adding an entry point to the new package setup.py
See https://docs.enthought.com/eam/application_bundles.html#application-bundles

items.title: Automated testing of examples

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
This issue is for adding automated testing for the examples in the `examples` folder.

As a first cut, the tests should make sure the scripts can be executed successfully assuming GUI (if any) will be closed immediately after opening.

Future issues can be open for more detailed automated testing for these examples.

(Opened in retrospect for #853)

items.title: Extract Demo App into an independently deployable package

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body: Currently the demo application is tied to the deployment of TraitsUI. Since TraitsUI is a library heavily depended on by other packages, it needs to be stable and should have fewer external dependencies. On the other hand, the demo application, um, is an application which can be developed and deployed more frequently and maybe with more external dependencies. The latter is more achievable if it is decoupled from TraitsUI.

items.title: TabularEditor crashes when reducing number of columns in adapter
items.body:
I have a custom TabularAdapter that changes dynamically the number of columns in a TabularEditor based on the size of the underlying variable.

When I reduce the number of columns, I get this crash:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\WinPython-64bit-3.8.3.0\python-3.8.3.amd64\lib\site-packages\traitsui\qt4\tabular_editor.py", line 913, in columnResized
    self.resizeColumnsToContents()
  File "C:\WinPython-64bit-3.8.3.0\python-3.8.3.amd64\lib\site-packages\traitsui\qt4\tabular_editor.py", line 894, in resizeColumnsToContents
    widths = compute_column_widths(
  File "C:\WinPython-64bit-3.8.3.0\python-3.8.3.amd64\lib\site-packages\traitsui\helper.py", line 168, in compute_column_widths
    widths[i] = user_width
IndexError: list assignment index out of range
```

It seems the issue is with the user width array which is still of the wrong size.
I am submitting a PR that fixes this by resetting the user widths when there is a mismatch in size.

items.title: Missing reverse action to Editor.sync_value
items.body:
Quite a number of editors use `sync_value` for adding change handlers onto a user's object, e.g.:

https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/25e6f83aec9c483b189ec43037440dd71bc4745d/traitsui/qt4/button_editor.py#L71

The `sync_value` is defined here:
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/0617cea882cbf0058469d00e5fd484df6bcbdca7/traitsui/editor.py#L346-L359

However there does not exist a method to reverse these hooks.
Consequently, when an editor is disposed, it might still be kept alive by these change handlers. Worse scenario: changes on the user objects may continue to update GUI components that are no longer valid.

Motivated by #431 and #752

items.title: TabularAdapter segfault on py3 + pyqt5
items.body:
The following script can be run from any Python 3 environment (3.6.0, 3.6.5, 3.6.9 and 3.6.10) with any version of pyqt5 (5.6, 5.7.1 and 5.14.2).

Steps to reproduce
- run script
- drag-and-drop any of the items to the bottom of the window (white space in the window, where the element list ends)
- crash!

<details>

```
from traits.api import HasTraits, Instance, List, Property, Str
from traitsui.api import ModelView, TabularAdapter, TabularEditor, UItem, View


class AnObject(HasTraits):
    name = Str


class AModel(HasTraits):
    alist = List


class ATabularAdapter(TabularAdapter):

    model_view = Instance(ModelView)

    #### 'TabularAdapter' protocol ############################################

    columns = [('name', 'name')]

    name_text = Property(depends_on='item')

    def _get_name_text(self):
        return self.item.name


class AModelView(ModelView):

    model = Instance(AModel)

    def default_traits_view(self):

        body = UItem(
            'model.alist',
            editor=TabularEditor(
                adapter=ATabularAdapter(model_view=self),
                editable=True,
                operations=['move'],
                show_titles=False,
                vertical_lines=False,
                horizontal_lines=False,
                multi_select=True,
            ),
            springy=True,
        )

        return View(body, resizable=True)


def main():
    am = AModel()
    for idx in range(10):
        am.alist.append(AnObject(name=str(idx)))

    amv = AModelView(model=am)
    amv.configure_traits()


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

</details>

items.title: Windows wx test interactions: remaining connection to old TextEditor instance

labels.name: component: test suite
labels.description: Issues related to testing, test support, test interactions...

items.body:
I found this while investigating errors on the following windows CI job https://ci.appveyor.com/project/EnthoughtOSS/traitsui/builds/33168227/job/j10vrs43kwn1qb0i

The root of the cause comes from these two tests and the error can be replicated when only the two of them are run together:
```
test_text_check_list_object_list (traitsui.tests.editors.test_check_list_editor.TestTextCheckListEditor) ... ok
test_text_check_list_object_str (traitsui.tests.editors.test_check_list_editor.TestTextCheckListEditor) ... Uncaught exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\appveyor\.edm\envs\traitsui-test-3.6-wx\lib\site-packages\traitsui\wx\check_list_editor.py", line 263, in update_object
    self.value = value
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'value' referenced before assignment
ERROR
```

The first test passes fine as there were no other check list `TextEditors` before it. In the second test, the error is raised during the call https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/64858b8c9ce9189a8c9cfde60610e4bd12f30962/traitsui/wx/ui_base.py#L98
because the `update_object` method of the check list `TextEditor` from the **previous** test is called. The control of that object is already removed (it is `None`), therefore, value assignment fails and this `UnboundLocalError` is raised.

I am not entirely sure what exactly the remaining connection to the old check list `TextEditor` is and why this is only happening on windows, but it seems to be related to the binding of https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/64858b8c9ce9189a8c9cfde60610e4bd12f30962/traitsui/wx/editor_factory.py#L115
Adding a `dispose` method to the editor that unbinds this specific event seems to fix the issue.

items.title: Demo application to use a single source of description instead of __init__.py / hard-coded image name

labels.name: component: demo
labels.description: Issues related to the demo code and application

items.body:
Currently the demo application has two ways to set the description of a folder:
(1) if `use_files` is true, parses the `__init__.py` file and extracts its docstring as the description
(2) if `use_files` is false, create reStructuredText inline to reference a specially named image file.

It would be better if the main description is provided by a single file in reStructuredText, e.g. `index.rst`.

Benefits:
~(1) We don't have to maintain the code that tokenize Python code just to extract the docstring~ Edited: Nope we still need this for displaying the description for individual Python scripts.
(2) While the `__init__.py` used typically only contains docstring, in theory it can contain arbitrary code that could fail or do all sort of fun things: It is unnecessary, we can avoid that.
(3) There will be only one way to provide a folder's main description.
(4) By adding a `__init__.py` just for providing the description, one inevitably turns a folder of example files into a Python package. This is seldomly a use case.  For example, this risks the example folder being erroneously picked up by setuptools machinery. By decoupling the description with `__init__.py`, one can have a non-package along with a description.

items.title: wx enum_editor doesn't use format_func when mapping values
items.body:
When `name` is specified on the editor factory, the mapping is done by the editor, not the factory. That is taken care of in `values_changed` method of the editor in qt4 but not wx.

wx:
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/e9f6b0cc03bbad20feb1f7e4f86ce2e174685fbb/traitsui/wx/enum_editor.py#L119-L124

qt4:
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/e9f6b0cc03bbad20feb1f7e4f86ce2e174685fbb/traitsui/qt4/enum_editor.py#L61-L66

Also, wx has its own version of `enum_value_changed` that is almost identical to `traitsui.helper.enum_values_changed` except for the lack of `strfunc` that is used to format values.

items.title: Import error  in wx/ui_panel.py: 'escape' moved from 'cgi' to `html`. FIX INCLUDED
items.body:
In Python 3.8 one observes the following error:
``` 
 File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/traits/has_traits.py", line 2019, in edit_traits
    return view.ui(
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/traitsui/view.py", line 446, in ui
    ui.ui(parent, kind)
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/traitsui/ui.py", line 244, in ui
    self.rebuild(self, parent)
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/traitsui/wx/toolkit.py", line 114, in ui_subpanel
    from . import ui_panel
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/traitsui/wx/ui_panel.py", line 30, in <module>
    from cgi \
ImportError: cannot import name 'escape' from 'cgi' (/usr/lib/python3.8/cgi.py)
```
As explained here: https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html#api-and-feature-removals `escape` was deprecated from `cgi` in 3.2 and was removed in 3.8. It should be imported from `html` instead

### FIX ###
Replace `cgi` in line 30 of `wx/ui_panel.py` with `html`

items.title: Add TabularAdapter to `traitsui.api`
items.body:
To use a `TabularEditor` it is almost invariably necessary to also use an instance of a `TabularAdapter`, resulting in the following typical imports:
```
from traitsui.api import Item, List, TabularEditor, View
from traitsui.tabular_adapter import TabularAdapter
```
It would be better to be able to import `TabularAdapter` from `traitsui.api`:
```
from traitsui.api import Item, List, TabularAdapter, TabularEditor, View
```

items.title: Bad TraitListEvent from ListStrEditor and TabularEditor

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
The `ListStrEditor` and `TabularEditor` create `TraitListEvents` with `removed` and `added` reversed. See: https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/3e2ce8604f8916ac68025c78fdc1985001d9c18b/traitsui/qt4/list_str_editor.py#L335

and: https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/3e2ce8604f8916ac68025c78fdc1985001d9c18b/traitsui/qt4/tabular_editor.py#L449

The signature of the [`TraitListEvent` initializer](https://github.com/enthought/traits/blob/c91e91eccaf8a892fd7141906b6bc92ae5f3f374/traits/trait_list_object.py#L44) is
```
def __init__ ( self, index = 0, removed = None, added = None ):
```

To avoid similar errors in the future, I recommend passing these arguments by keyword instead of by position. I think we should also make them keyword-only in Traits.

I'd mark this with "Good first issue", except that I think writing the tests may be nontrivial.

items.title: format_func applied to Item's for which it was not specified

labels.name: ETS Backlog
labels.description: Good issue for ETS team members to look at

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
The example below on TraitsUI 6.1.3 produces the window:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1588456/80219284-dc788380-8607-11ea-8558-205db3fd10df.png)

where the second Item has had the `format_func` (only specified in the first Item) applied. A workaround is to specify `format_func=lambda s: s` in the second Item.

```python
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *

class Foo(HasStrictTraits):
    thing = Str('a_thing')
    things = Str('one, two, three_four')

    traits_view = View(
        Item('thing', format_func=lambda s: s.replace('_', ' ').title()),
        Item('things')
    )

Foo().configure_traits()
```

items.title: Replace use of traits_view trait with default_traits_view method
items.body:
A future release of `traits` will warn about any redefinition of traits/methods with a prefix `trait` or `_trait`, see this issue: https://github.com/enthought/traits/issues/705

Currently `traits_view` has been used various places in `traitsui` and have been mentioned in the user documentation as a way to provide the default view.

One can easily switch to overriding the `default_traits_view` method to avoid this warning.

items.title: format_func not used when EnumEditor is initialized with static values

labels.name: ETS Backlog
labels.description: Good issue for ETS team members to look at

milestone.title: Release 7.0.1
milestone.description:
Bugfix release for TraitsUI 7.0, including particularly for anything which might be caused by Traits 6.1.

This release is scheduled for after the release of Traits 6.1

items.body:
To reproduce:
```

class Foo(HasTraits):

    true_or_false = Int()

    def default_traits_view(self):
        return View(
            Item(
                "true_or_false",
                editor=EnumEditor(
                    values=[0, 1],
                    format_func=lambda v: str(bool(v)).upper(),
                )
            )
        )

foo = Foo()
foo.configure_traits()
```

One expects to see the "TRUE" and "FALSE" in the dropdown. However one gets "0" and "1" in the view, which is unexpected.
![Screenshot 2020-04-14 at 17 10 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3673984/79247987-224c8380-7e73-11ea-823a-9d26e124e619.png)

Printing the mapping:
```

ui = foo.edit_traits()
editor, = ui.get_editors("true_or_false")
print(editor.mapping)
ui.dispose()
```
We get:
```
{'0': 0, '1': 1}
```

If I create the editor first and then mutates the `values`, then I get the expected behaviour:
```
    def default_traits_view(self):
        editor = EnumEditor(
            format_func=lambda v: str(bool(v)).upper(),
        )
        # trigger _values_changed to fire
        editor.values = [0, 1] 
        return View(
            Item(
                "true_or_false",
                editor=editor,
            )
        )
```
![Screenshot 2020-04-14 at 17 14 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3673984/79248235-77889500-7e73-11ea-8ee3-a99ea05dfe32.png)

items.title: WxPython ColorEditor segfault
items.body:
When using the `ColourComboBox` (or indeed, a plain `OwnerDrawnComboBox`), there is a segfault on exit on MacOS, but only if the drop-down window has bee accessed.  It looks like this is a potential problem with cleaning up the temporary window used to display the menu.

Workaround is to use a straight `ComboBox`.

items.title: RGBColorEditor uses mapped value even when color isn't string

labels.name: ETS Backlog
labels.description: Good issue for ETS team members to look at

items.body:
This is for Qt. I have not checked wx.

The [`RGBColorTrait`](https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/277bd2a93006ab4d7a02e9ad6024bab190681976/traitsui/qt4/rgb_color_trait.py#L97-L100) allows both RGB tuples and strings, of which the latter is a mapped trait. This causes funny business because a direct assignment of an RGB tuple does not update the mapped value.

The [`RGBColorEditor` gives precedence](https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/277bd2a93006ab4d7a02e9ad6024bab190681976/traitsui/qt4/rgb_color_editor.py#L42-L45) to the mapped trait, which causes situations like this:

```python
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *


class Thing(HasTraits):
    color = RGBColorTrait()

    def _color_default(self):
        return (0.1, 0.2, 0.3)

    view = View(
        Item('color')
    )


t = Thing()
t.configure_traits()
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1588456/77171418-72117800-6a8a-11ea-990b-e7c5fa7c3196.png)


The background color for the editor appears as white because the mapped `color_` is not synchronized to the unmapped value.

items.title: CheckListEditor fails with mixed types
items.body:
How to handle mixed type lists with the check list editor is unclear.

### Example:
```python
from traits.api import *
from traitsui.api import *

class Foo(HasTraits):
    items = List([1, 'two'])
    selected = List
    
    traits_view = View(
        Item('selected', style='custom',
             editor=CheckListEditor(name='items'))
    )

foo = Foo()
foo.configure_traits()
print(foo.selected)
```
fails with:
```
.../traitsui/qt4/check_list_editor.py", line 48, in <lambda>
    capitalize = lambda s: s.capitalize()
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'capitalize'
```
which is apparently simply [due to the fact that the first element is stringy](https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/277bd2a93006ab4d7a02e9ad6024bab190681976/traitsui/qt4/check_list_editor.py#L80).

If instead the `items` is defined like, e.g., `items = List([1, 'two'])`, then a different failure is observed:
```
.../traitsui/qt4/check_list_editor.py", line 101, in <listcomp>
    self.values = valid_values = [x[0] for x in values]
TypeError: 'int' object is not subscriptable
```
since it is assumed that `values[0] != string type` => `values == list of (value, name)`, but which is not the case.

It seems like this could be a straightforward fix in `traitsui/qt4/check_list_editor.py` by first checking if all the elements are not a tuple, then checking whether all the elements are stringy. If neither are the case, then I think we could recast `values`. Something like
```python
if not all(is_value_name_pair(v) for v in values):
    values = [(v, capitalize(sv(v))) for v in values]
```
where
```python
def is_value_name_pair(item):
    return (isinstance(item, tuple) and
            len(item) == 2 and
            isinstance(item[1], six.string_types)
```

The error message returned from that failing test is:

> File "C:\Users\tombr\Documents\workspace\git_traitsui\traitsui\wx\table_editor.py", line 478, in dispose

  File "c:\users\tombr\documents\workspace\git_pyface\pyface\ui\wx\grid\grid.py", line 416, in dispose

wx._core.wxAssertionError: C++ assertion "GetEventHandler() == this" failed at ..\..\src\common\wincmn.cpp(478) in wxWindowBase::~wxWindowBase(): any pushed event handlers must have been removed

The reason for this error is that the

items.title: Cannot explicitly set TupleEditor as the editor for a ValidatedTuple
items.body:
Setting the argument `editor=TupleEditor()` for a `traits.api.ValidatedTuple` in a view, throws an error. Here is the minimal reproducible example:
```
from traits.api import HasTraits, Int, ValidatedTuple
from traitsui.api import Item, TupleEditor, View


class MyTrait(HasTraits):
    a = ValidatedTuple(Int(0), Int(1), fvalidate=lambda x: x[0] < x[1])

    traits_view = View(Item('a', editor=TupleEditor()))


if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_trait = MyTrait()
    my_trait.configure_traits()
```
The error is due to the facts that `ValidatedTuple` is derived from `BaseTuple`, not `Tuple`, and that the `types` attribute of the `TupleEditor` factory is not set. See --
https://github.com/enthought/traitsui/blob/18b92cf73ebce4436d98aba1f16b1132bff4c7af/traitsui/editors/tuple_editor.py#L155-L158

items.title: Test traitsui.extras.tests in CI
items.body: Currently the tests in `traitsui.extras.tests` aren't run as part of the CI runs. That should be fixed.

items.title: Rename DateTimeEditor to DatetimeEditor
items.body:
See enthought/traits#811, which proposed renaming the `DateTime` trait type to `Datetime`.

Either both these changes should happen, or neither.

items.title: Changing the selected row in a TableEditor doesn't redraw correctly
items.body:
On Linux (Ubuntu 16.04), this happens with PyQt4 and PyQt5.

(Testing on Mac underway)

Selecting a row in the `TableEditor` with a mouse click works as expected. However, if the trait that is linked to the "`selected`" attribute of a `TableEditor` is changed programmatically, the redraw is partial (triggering the redraw by, for instance, using the scrollbar, fixes the issue).

![Peek 2020-01-13 15-09](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7642150/72266707-d4777380-3616-11ea-9b67-0e19af1c2719.gif)

This example:
```python
import random

from traits.api import (
    HasTraits, HasStrictTraits, List, Int, Regex, Str, Button, Instance,
    Property)
from traitsui.api import VGroup, UItem, View, TableEditor
from traitsui.table_column import ObjectColumn


class Employee(HasTraits):
    eid = Int
    first_name = Str
    last_name = Str
    age = Int
    phone = Regex(value='000-0000', regex=r'\d\d\d[-]\d\d\d\d')


class Department(HasStrictTraits):

    employees = List(Employee)
    selected = Instance(Employee)
    random_select = Button()
    this_employee = Property(depends_on="selected")

    def _random_select_changed(self):
        self.selected = random.choice(self.employees)
    
    def _get_this_employee(self):
        empl = self.selected
        if empl is not None:
            return f"{empl.eid}) {empl.first_name} {empl.last_name}"
        else:
            return ""

    traits_view = View(
        VGroup(
            UItem('random_select'),
            UItem(
                'employees',
                editor=TableEditor(
                    columns=[
                        ObjectColumn(name='eid', editable=False),
                        ObjectColumn(name='first_name', editable=False),
                        ObjectColumn(name='last_name', editable=False),
                        ObjectColumn(name='age', editable=False),
                        ObjectColumn(name='phone', editable=False),
                    ],
                    selected="selected",
                )),
            UItem("this_employee", style="readonly")
        )
    )


demo = Department(employees=[
    Employee(
        eid=i,
        first_name=random.choice(["Ada", "Bob", "Claire", "Damian", "Elisa"]),
        last_name=random.choice(["Fitz", "Griffin", "Hack", "Iba", "Jordan"]),
        age=random.randrange(18, 112),
        phone="{0:03d}-{0:04d}".format(
            random.randrange(999), random.randrange(9999))
    ) for i in range(14)
])

if __name__ == '__main__':
    demo.configure_traits()

```

items.title: Make docutils an optional dependency of traitsui
items.body: `traitsui/extras/demo.py` and `tutor.py` require `docutils` to convert restructured text into html. It is not clear if `docutils` should be made a dependency of `traitsui` because its not being used anywhere else. After offline discussion, we decided to make it an `extras` dependency in `setup.py`. In future if HTML editor in `traitsui` requires `docutils` it could be made a core dependency.

items.title: ShellEditor + NumPy
items.body:
Hi there,

I use ShellPython to run Python commands in my app.
Works well.

BTW, as I often (to not say always) need and use NumPy functions, I wonder how it would be possible to import automatically NumPy when I launch ShellEditor.

Thanks in advance.
